definition: cave/hole/zero (unambiguous spoken form when spelling out numbers)/CL:個|个[ge4]

sentences.english: He ordered the land to be dug and trenched.
sentences.chinese: 他命令在這片土地上挖洞並挖好戰壕。

sentences.english: The dog is clawing a hole.
I can't keep him, he digs holes in my garden.
sentences.chinese: 我不能養它了，它在我的花園裏挖洞。

sentences.english: Later, you dig a hole beneath the boulder and lift out a pair of Surefooted Boots.
sentences.chinese: 然後，你在那巨石下挖洞弄出了一雙穩當之靴。

sentences.english: NOT FAR from where I dug the hole, a lilac tree is coming into flower.
sentences.chinese: 離我挖洞的地方不遠處，一棵丁香樹正在開花。

sentences.english: Inside the guards’ room, on P.I., the team furthers their progress digging the hole.
sentences.chinese: 在警衛室裏，PI工作組繼續按計劃挖洞。

sentences.english: I will borrow a small measure, and measure it, while you dig the hole.
sentences.chinese: 我去借個小稱，然後稱一稱，在你挖洞的時候。

sentences.english: At the start, jump into the concrete pit, dig and drop through.
sentences.chinese: 在關卡開始時，跳進水泥洞中，挖洞，然後跳下去。

sentences.english: Hares dig holes in the ground to live in.
I must grow donkey ears if don't dig a hole to tell.
sentences.chinese: 如果不挖洞訴說我也要長驢耳朵了。

sentences.english: Keep digging until the enemies have brought down all the gold. Retreat to higher ground and dig there, if necessary.
sentences.chinese: 一直挖洞直到敵人幫您把所有金塊都拿下來。

sentences.english: They began to dig into the hill.
They lived on fish and meat and used to make holes in the ice and catch fish and seals.
sentences.chinese: 他們一魚和肉爲主食，常在冰上挖洞，捕捉魚和海豹。

sentences.english: He dug himself out of prison.
The long Gungan face has a tough yet flexible bill for burrowing and rooting out food.
sentences.chinese: 岡根人的長臉上長着堅韌的喙，用來挖洞和拱出食物。

definition: to punch a hole/to drill a hole/to dig a hole/to burrow
to bore/to burrow/to crawl through a tunnel
to dig into/to cut a mine into
to conceal oneself/to go into hiding/to take cover
carpenter's plane/to plane (woodwork)/to shave off/to peel (with a potato peeler etc)
to dig/to excavate/(coll.) to exclude/not to count/to deduct/to subtract
to chop wood/to chop down trees
to live in a cave/(of animals) to be of burrowing habit
